Comment: She always used this move as White. We tried many counters, none of them worked.
J. B. had never played this, but he'd read in a book it was a good move, so he decided to try it.
Miss L. of course formed an ideal center.
This was as much of the book as J. B. remembered. We weren't professionals and didn't try to memorize the first 10 moves of every opening variation.
The game starts here, with the first actual piece being developed.
J. B. wanted to dissipate Miss L.'s center quickly.
Miss L. now centralizes her Knight and regains the Pawn.
J. B. decides to get his pieces out as well.
Miss L. prepares for castling Q-side. But J. B. didn't see the tactical fine point this move also holds.
J. B. tries to continue his development. However, it was necessary to play 5... P-K3 to prevent...
...this! The game ends with a lightning-bolt move.
